Pseudo Place of publication unknown Ami de l'adolescence 40; 41; Ami de l'adolescence NA NA French NA NA n.pl. ? NA NA NA NA 2 NA NA NA NA Attribution - the STN sold multiple editions under this title. Moreover, 'L'Ami de l'adolescence' was often bundled and sold together with 'L'Ami des enfans', and in some of these instances they were accounted for together under a single title as 'L'Ami des enfans & adolescence.' Where this has occured, sales have been recorded in the database against both superbooks, i.e. 'L'Ami des enfans' and 'L'Ami de l'adolescence'. See also 'Ami des enfans'. Fauche-Borel Catalogue (1787) lists an edition of 'L'Ami de l'adolescence' in 4 volumes (Geneva 1786). However, as editions have been impossible to disagregate, all sales are assumed to be of 2 volume editions. Ami de l'adolescence

Pseudo Place of publication unknown Ami (l') des enfans 42; 43; Ami (l') des enfans, par Berquin; Ami (l') des enfans, par Roshau; Ami des enfans; Ami des enfans par Lechauve; Ami des enfans par Rochaw NA NA French NA NA n.pl. ? NA NA NA NA 1 NA NA NA NA Attribution - the STN sold multiple works and editions that they accounted for under this title, and since it is usually only possible to distinguish between them in the periods where rencontres (STN stock books) exist, they have all been accounted for as a single edition and superbook. The majority were the work of Berquin, but certainly not all. The various editions comprised anything from 1 and 10 volumes. Moreover, 'L'Ami des enfans' was often bundled and sold together with 'L'Ami de l'adolescence', and in some of these instances the two works were accounted for under a single title as 'L'Ami des enfans & adolescence.' Where this has occured, sales have been recorded in the database against both superbooks, i.e. 'L'Ami des enfans' and 'L'Ami de l'adolescence'. Ami (l') des enfans

Pseudo Place of publication unknown Edelzinde, fille d'Amalazonte, reine des Goths 362; Edelzinde; Edelzinde fille d'Amalazonte, reine des Goths NA NA French NA NA n.pl. ? NA NA NA NA 2 NA NA NA NA Notes: Attribution - MS1007 states Paris, 1780 as does Fauche-Borel Catalogue (1787). The STN bought in 200 copies of this edition from Gay frères in August/ September 1780, but they were almost sold out at the moment the STN produced their own edition of 200 copies in January 1781. On 9 March 1781, the STN bought a further 50 copies of this edition, which they sold over the next five years. Sales figures and dating of transactions suggest that all the copies whose sales are recorded in the database belong to this edition rather than the STN's own edition. Edelzinde

Pseudo Place of publication unknown Théatre de Le Sage Théatre de Le sage NA NA French NA NA n.pl. ? NA NA NA NA 2 NA 12 NA NA Attribution - Superbook attribution uncertain; precise edition not definite. Most likely this was the 'Oeuvres de théâtre de Le Sage' Nouvelle éd, rev. & corrigée (Paris: Chez la Veuve Duchesne, 1774) or the 'Recueil des pièces mises au Théâtre François par M. Le Sage' (Maestricht: Dufour, 1774). Both were two volume collections containing the same texts in the same order. As the STN are known to have traded the latter edition in the late 1780s, it is more likely that this was the edition indicated here. It should also be noted here that Le Sage produced a three volume work called 'Le Théâtre de la foire ou l'Opéra comique' (Amsterdam: Hôtel Serpente, 1783). Recueil des pièces mises au Théâtre François par M. Le Sage

Pseudo Livres en Société: STN joint editions Incas (les), ou la destruction de l'empire du Pérou   689; 690; Incas; Incas (les) NA NA French NA NA Berne; Lausanne; Neuchâtel? Berne; Lausanne; Neuchâtel? 1777 NA NA NA 2 NA 12 29 presumably STN edition too, is clear from catalogues that in 8 and in 12 both produced. Attribution - MS1007 states Neuchatel 1777 Surviving records do not indicate the origin of the 1,544 copies of this work that the STN received on 9 March 1777, but the large numbers and the fact that it was accounted for later under 'nos editions' suggest that it is was an STN printing. However, no 1777 STN edition has been located. Schmidt includes the work in his bibliography of probable STN editions that have not been located. However, the STN never sold the work to the Société Typographique de Lausanne, and only ever sent a handful to the Société Typographique de Berne, though they later bought copies from the Société Typographique de Lausanne. This suggests that the unrecorded IN copies may have been printed in Berne or Lausanne for the STN?. Fauche-Borel Catalogue (1787) also gives a (Lausanne, 1780) edition, and some later sales may be attributable to this edition. Incas (les)

Watermark evidence reveals this work was produced in Rouen. NB. There are four subsequent 'Amsterdam Délaissé' editions, the last two of which date from 1775 but STN sources and Louis Fauche-Borel 'Catalogue' (1787) indicate the 1764 edition. Nevertheless from May 1787, many out transactions may refer to the Bruysset editions, and there is also a strong possibility that the copies brought from Jean Racine of Rouen on 26 May 1787 were a two volume edition published by Racine himself in that year.  We thank David W. Smith for this information. Lettres d'une Péruvienne

Pseudo Place of publication unknown Lucrèce: de la nature des choses Lucrèce. Traduction nouvelle avec des notes par M. L* G* De rerum natura Latin French NA NA n.pl. ? NA NA NA NA 1 NA NA NA NA Attribution: edition not known: several produced with various translators. Superbook attribution is also uncertain. MS data could also refer to 'Lucrece', a tragedy published by Dufour (Londres et Paris, 1765), though dating makes this unlikely. As the STN acquired their copies from Lyon in late 1787, it is probable that they were the (Paris, 1788) edition published by Moutard. The most recent previous French edition appears to be 1768. Darnton records orders for the 1768 edition from Chevrier in Poitiers, but there is no evidence in STN accounting sources that it was ever despatched. As 'De rerum natura' is the only extant work by Lucretius, there is can be doubt as to which of the author's works are indicated by the MS, if it refers to the person and not the tragedy. Lucrèce

Certain British editions Supplément au Roman comique, ou mémoires pour servir à la vie de Jean Monnet, ci-devant Directeur de l'Opéra-Comique à Paris, de l'Opéra de Lyon et d'une Comédie française à Londres. Ecrits par lui-même Supplément au Roman comique, ou mémoires pour servir à la vie de Jean Monnet, ci-devant Directeur de l'Opéra-Comique à Paris, de l'Opéra de Lyon et d'une Comédie française à Londres. Ecrits par lui-même; Vie de Jean Monnet NA NA French NA NA London London 1772 NA NA NA 2 NA 12 NA NA Attribution - sourced from the putative author, only extant edition available at time STN traded in work.  N.B. The authorship of this complex work, and whether it is a genuine biography, has been subject to some doubt. Martin et al, 'Bibliographie du genre romanesque', note that Michaud uses it as a major source for his biographical article on Monnet, but they refrain from naming Monnet as the author. They also note that regardless of the authenticity of the memoirs, they deserve to be included in their bibliography of fictional works because at vol. 2, pp. 107-288 of the 1772 edition there is a 'romanesque work' entitled 'Les mystifications du Sr P***' which tells of the adventures of a 'comedien'. The fact that this book is sourced from Monnet himself is suggestive evidence concerning its authorship. Supplément au Roman comique

Probable Commissioned STN edition Tableau de Paris 1279; Tableau de Paris NA NA French NA Société Typographique de Neuchâtel Amsterdam Neuchâtel 1782 NA [2], XVI, 319, [1 bl.]; [2], 352; [2], 352; [2], 331, [1bl.] 1380 4 NA 8 NA STN Catalogue 1785 'le même livre 8. 4 vol. qui contiennent tout ce qu'il y a dans l'édition en 8 volumes'. Attribution - known STN edition. After Schmidt, 'Liste des impressions' and transactions data this was a commissioned edition for Jonas Fauche. Edition details not fully resolved. There are strong hints that the STN sold their eight volume set bound in 4 vols. The STN Catalogue 1785 refers to a four volume edition as 'le même livre 8 [i.e. in-8°]. 4 vol. qui contiennent tout ce qu'il y a dans l'édition en 8 volumes', but no such edition has been identified. A part sale of a 4 vol. set to Poincot on 20 June 1783 is recorded as 'les 4 premiers cahiers de tome 3 & 4 de la petite edition', suggesting an edition in which these two volumes were bound together as one. Presumably the rest of the set also comprised 'double volumes', which is consistent with the catalogue entry. Because edition history for this superbook is so uncertain, no 'Assumed printings' have been recorded. Tableau de Paris

Certain STN editions Tableau de Paris Suite de Tabeau de Paris; Tableau de Paris NA NA French NA Société Typographique de Neuchâtel Amsterdam Neuchâtel 1783 1782-1783 NA NA 8 NA 8 NA NA Attribution - '1783' date of publication is taken from STN catalogue 1785, but this is the only extant 8 volume 'Amsterdam' edition identified. Date on title page, pagination and page layouts confirm that the first four volumes of this edition are the 1782 STN edition; the final four volumes, dated 1783, contained new material. The first in transaction for vols 5-8, recording 500 copies received from Jonas Fauche, Ch. S. Favre et cie. on 18 June 1783, suggests that Fauche and Favre probably printed the final volumes of the set, but as in transactions for this period are mostly lacking, this remains conjecture. Tableau de Paris

Certain Other Swiss editions Mémoires authentiques de Mme la comtesse du Barry Mémoires authentiques de Mme la comtesse du Barry# The Authentic Memoirs of the Countess de Barre, The French King's Mistress English French NA NA London Geneva? 1775 1775 NA NA 2 NA in-12° NA NA Attribution - sourced from 1775, transactions data suggests Geneva probable real place of publication. No two volume edition of this work has been traced. The only extant 1775 edition claims to be published in 'Londres: aux dépens des éditeurs' is only 188 pages long. The only previous editions are from 1772. The title-page of the work proclaims that it was 'par le chevalier Fr. N.', who is usually assumed to be Nogaret, and 'Traduit de l'anglois'. As an English 'second edition' dated 1771 survives, this improbable sounding claim appears to be correct. Except for the final pages, telling of Du Barry's relations with Louis XV, this work is essentially a piece of creative erotic fiction.  Mémoires authentiques de Mme la comtesse du Barry

Roson & G. Reily), could be the 1775 London [Geneva ?] edition, as sometimes works published late in one year appeared with the date of the following year. Certain Livres en Société: STN joint editions Edelzinde, fille d'Amalzonté, reine des Goths Edelzinde, fille d'Amalzonté, reine des Goths NA NA French Sociétè Typographique de Neuchâtel NA n.pl. Neuchâtel 1781 NA NA NA 2 NA NA NA NA Notes: Attribution - Schmidt annexe records that the STN printed 200 copies of this edition, and manuscript data dates this event to 1 January 1781. Database appears to contain no recorded sales for this edition for the six weeks following its printing: it was presumably shipped to client(s) in January to early March 1781. Manuscript annotation 'à faire le compte comme à 1000' suggests this may have been a commissioned edition or part of a joint-enterprise, perhaps involving the Société Typographique de Berne and the Société Typographique de Lausanne. The STN bought in 50 copies of another edition on 9 March 1781 and these appear to have been the copies they sold over the following few years. Edelzinde

Certain STN editions Cours abrégé de géographie historique, ancienne & moderne, et de sphère: par demandes & réponses. Quatrième édition, revue, corrigée et augmentée par l'auteur Geographie historique NA NA French Société Typographique de Neuchâtel NA Neuchâtel Neuchâtel 1774 NA NA NA 2 NA NA NA NA Attribution - known STN edition.  The STN published editions of both the  'Cours abrégé de géographie historique' and the 'Cours abrégé de géographie élémentaire' in 1770 (when they printed both a combined edition under the title 'Cours abrégé de géographie historique' and a stand alone edition of the 'Géographie élémentaire'), in 1774, in 1782, in 1783 and in 1789. They also published an edition of the 'Cours abrégé de géographie élémentaire' in 1788. On some occasions they bundled the short 'Géographie élémentaire' with the longer 'Géographie historique', while on others they sold them separately. Where just 'geographie' is recorded in the manuscripts, it referred, according to the STN's standard practice, either to the 1770 combined edition (which appears under the superbook title 'Géographie par Ostervald', or to a bundled set of both works, in which case a sale has been recorded under the separate superbooks for the 'Géographie historique' and 'Géographie élémentaire'.  Cours abrégé de géographie historique

Pseudo Place of publication unknown Forme du gouvernement de Suède Forme du Gouvernement de Suède NA NA French NA NA n.pl. ? NA NA NA NA 1 NA NA 9 NA Attribution - edition(s) not identified. First published under the title 'Forme du gouvernement de Suede, avec quelques autres pièces concernant le droit public de ce royaume imprimés pour la dernière fois à Stockholm, en 1755, par ordre des Etats' (Copenhagen and Geneva, 1756) and updated as 'Forme du gouvernement de Suède ratifiée par le Roi et les Etats du royaume, à Stockholm le 21 Août 1772, avec les discours prononcés à la diète, à l'occasion de sa clôture' (Versailles, 1772) . STN sourced copies from Philibert in Geneva, who jointly published the 1756 edition and then published another in 1775. Since STN sales all postdate the royal coup of 1772 that changed the form of government, it seems likely that they all relate to an edition of the 1772 version. Forme du gouvernement de Suède

Pseudo Place of publication unknown Histoire des religieux de la Compagnie de Jesus Histoire des Jésuits NA NA French NA NA n.pl. ? NA NA NA NA 3 NA NA 65 NA Attribution - edition not identified, several produced.  Superbook attribution uncertain - for all but the copy sourced from Haller and suplied to Carli-Ribbi in 1779, which was certainly this work. Manuscript information gives 'Histoire des jesuites', which could indicate several works, especially Linguet's 'Histoire impartiale des Jesuites' (n.p., 1768). However, Darnton 'Corpus' attributes the sale to Billaut in Tours to Quesnel's work, and manuscript information gives '65 sheets' which may make this more likely than Linguet's work (which was 2 volumes in-12°, c.900 pages). Neverthless, the lastest edition of Quesnel's work located was published in 1751, so attribution must remain subject to some caution. Histoire des religieux de la Compagnie de Jesus

RERO has title under 'Mémoire historique sur la dernière année de la vie de Frédéric II, roi de Prusse: avec l'avant-propos de son histoire, écrite par lui-même / lu dans l'assemblée publique de l'Académie de Berlin, le 25 janvier 1787 par le comte Hertzberg, curateur & membre de l'Académie' but notes the alternative title, given here. Edition was sold both with or without the 'Histoire complète de la Dissertation sur la littérature allemande, avec la correspondance entre S.M. & S.E. le comte de Hertzberg à ce sujet'. 461 copies were printed with the 'Histoire', and 568 without, but manuscript information does not note which sales were which, so the two variant editions are combined here. Pseudo Commissioned STN edition Tableau de la monarchie française Tableau de la monarchie française NA NA French NA Société Typographique de Neuchâtel n.pl. Neuchâtel 1771 NA NA NA 1 NA NA NA 1777 presumed edition which Barbier says is this work (http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k73356k/f3.image.r=les+quatre+ages+de+la+monarchie+francoise.langEN) Attribution - hitherto unknown STN edition, all copies of which were sent to the author; no record of this title has been found in library catalogues. However, according to Barbier the first volume of an intended four volumes of the 'Tableau de la Monarchie française' was published by Grangé in Paris in 1777 under the title 'Histoire politique du gouvernement françois ou Les quatre âges de la monarchie françoise. Tome premier', which survives. Assuming Barbier is right, it seems probable that the STN edition was reissued under the Grangé imprint. Goëzman spent most of the early 1770s in a legal battle with Beaumarchais after which he was disgraced, and this may explain the long delay before publication. NB. Multiple spellings exist for the surname of this magistrate and later secret agent. In the STN archive his name is usually spelt Götzmann, but this database uses the spelling Goëzman, which is more familiar in the literature and apparently the author's preferred form. Tableau de la monarchie française

La même édition 8vo, avec les mêmes planches sous presse. Did these editions exist, or just the 1789 one? Attribution - STN edition, although the protracted publishing history of this edition appears complicated and has never been investigated. Work on the edition appears to have began from 1782, although not completed until 1789. The Fauche-Borel Catalogue 1787 gives octavo (in 3 volumes) and folio editions, which are described as respectively under press and proposed by subscription. It is unlikely that the folio edition was ever achieved, although the octavo edition was. Histoire des conquêtes de Gustave-Adolfe

NA NA NA NA 1 NA 12 NA La Sade to his wife 2 Dec 1779 'I am distressed that the author [Abbé Joseph de La Porte] of the Voyageur français is ill. He is a wonderful writer. Read this book if you want to read something delightful. I know nothing so informative and at the same time so amusing. I promise you that this is the first book that my son will read. Keep me informed how this writer is doing. I have a special interest in him because of the delightful nights I spent with him last winter, and this one . . . A Father Inquisitor, a fellow-traveler in the Holy Office, an itinerant knife-sharpener from Auvergne, all that filthy scum will live ‘til eighty, because they say that it is the peculiar nature of all the most useless and harmful creatures to live longer than the others, and an abbé de La Porte, a delightful and charming author, who ought to be the ornament of his society as he is of those who read him, will be cut down in the midst of his career and will not have the glory of finishing his work! . . . And yet Providence is just! . . . ' Attribution - edition and volume information unknown. Voyageur françois

Biblos 18 notes that the Gabriel Grasset Catalogue 1776 gives an edition of this work as (Lausanne sous Londres) and states that the (Londres, 1772) edition was examined and found to have none of the characteristics of Lausanne editions of the period. Certain Commissioned STN edition Discours oratoire contenant l’éloge de S.E.M. le chevalier André Tron Discours de Tron; Discours oratoire; Discours oratoire contenant l’éloge de S.E.M. le chevalier André Tron NA NA French NA Société Typographique de Neuchâtel n.pl. Neuchâtel 1774 NA NA NA 1 NA 4 10, 28, 49 Included Discours oratoire de Plombal in these too?? Attribution - STN edition mentioned by Schmidt 'Liste des impressions [annexe]' as not having been located, confirmed or examined. Transactions data confirms attribution but extant copies of edition not located.  The only surviving copy of this work located is a 39 page pamphlet in Yale University with almost identical title, 'Discours oratoire contenant l'éloge de son Excellence, Monsieur le Chevalier André Tron ... élu à la dignité de procurateur de Saint Marc'. This edition claims to have been published in Venice in 1773 by C. Palese. The name Carlo Palese is associated with several other French and Italian language editions around this period, but it remains possible that in this case the Palese imprint is false and that this is the STN edition. There does not seem to have been an Italian edition of this work. Discours oratoire contenant l’éloge de S.E.M. le chevalier André Tron

Pseudo Place of publication unknown Essai historique sur la vie de Marie Antoinette d'Autriche, reine de France, pour servir à l'histoire de cette princesse Essai historique sur la vie sur Marie Antoinette NA NA French NA NA n.pl. ? NA NA NA NA 1 NA NA NA NA Attribution - edition not identified, numerous produced from 1789, when copies seized at their printshop were recovered from the Bastille. N.B. The standard attribution of this pamphlet to Goupil appears to be wrong, at least in part. Goupil died in prison in 1778, but this biography discusses events from 1781. In fact, the work emanated from A network of libellistes run by Jacquet de Douai. (See Simon Burrows, 'Blackmail, Scandal and Revolution'). Essai historique sur la vie de Marie Antoinette d'Autriche

Pseudo Place of publication unknown Gazette (la) noire, par un homme qui n'est pas blanc, ou oeuvres posthumes du Gazetier cuirassé Gazette noire NA NA French NA NA n.pl. ? 1784 NA NA NA 1 NA 8 NA NA Attribution - edition not identified. STN sourced the work in 1784, when first published, although probable that more than one edition published in that year. N.B. Simon Burrows 'A King's Ransom' (2010) and Robert Darnton 'The Devil in the Holy Water' (2010) both independently concluded that the likely author of this pamphlet was Anne-Gédéon La Fite de Pelleport, rather than Morande, to whom it has traditionally been attributed. French police records and Jacques-Pierre Brissot's interrogation records support this conclusion. Gazette (la) noire

At least two editions of this work were produced under the false imprint (Paris, 1776), one by Gabriel Grasset in Geneva and this one, by Jean-Pierre Heubach in Lausanne. The STN sourced the majority of their copies from Lausanne and only ever accounted for a single edition. Thus they probably never traded in the Grasset edition. Certain Place of publication unknown Oeufs rouges. Première partie. Sorhouet mourant à M. de Maupeou, chancelier de France Oeuf rouge; Oeufs rouges NA NA French NA NA n.pl. ? 1772 NA 64, [2] 66 1 NA 12 NA NA Attribution - only extant edition located. This was a highly illegal work, and this may explain why it is sometimes referred to in the STN archives under the apparently coded (but rather transparent) Latin title as 'De Ovo Rubro'. (A coded title was also used for d'Holbach's 'Système de la Nature' under the title 'Ouvrage de Boubers'). No extant Latin translation has been detected, and the fact that a consignment of books sent to Deinet and later returned by him is referred to under both titles appears to prove that 'De Ovo Rubro' indeed refers to the French edition of 'Oeufs rouges'. On the clandestine publication and dissemination of this pamphlet in France, see Mairobert, Journal Historique De La Révolution Opérée Dans La Constitution De La Monarchie Françoise, III, 127, entry for 23 May 1772. Oeufs rouges

Certain Livres en Société: STN joint editions Recueil de diverses pièces servant de supplément à l'histoire philosophique et politique des établissemens et du commerce des Européens dans les deux Indes par Guillaume-Thomas Raynal 1163; 1164; Lettres à Raynal; Recueil de diverses pièces servant de supplément à l'histoire philosophique et politique des établissemens et du commerce des Européens dans les duex Indes par Guillaume-Thomas Raynal NA NA French Libraires associés Jean Abraham Nouffer; Société Typographique de Neuchâtel Geneva; Neuchâtel Geneva; Neuchâtel 1784 NA [4], 430 434 1 NA 8 NA Is the10th volume of the 1783-1784 edition of Raynal's work Attribution - known STN edition produced in association with Nouffer, who shared half of the costs.  N.B. STN Catalogue 1785 shows both in-8° and in-12° editions produced, which are not separable in all sales. Details given here are for in-8° edition. RERO suggests the Recueil published as 10th volume of the 1783-1784 edition of Raynal's work. Transactions recorded for 'Lettres à Raynal' in Brouillard are assimilated to this work in MS1007, suggesting the two were joined from an unknown date.   See: Claudette Fortuny "La troisième édition de l'"Histoire des deux Indes" et ses contrefaçons", in: SVEC: Studies on Voltaire and the Eighteenth Century; 2001, 12, p. 269-297. The Recueil contains: Lettre à l'abbé Raynal, fur les affaires de l'Amerique; Arrêt de la Cour de parlement, qui condamne L'Histoire philosophique & politique des deux Indes; Censure de la faculté de théologie de Paris contre L'Histoire philosophique & politique, etc.; La Nymphe de Spa à L'abbé Raynal. NA NA NA NA 1 NA NA NA NA Attribution: work unidentified but could possibly be Jean-Bernard Bossu's 'Nouveaux voyages aux Indes Occidentales; contenant une relation des differens peuples qui habitent les environs du grand fleuve Saint-Louis, appelle vulgairement le Mississippi' (Paris, Le Jay, 1768). The title of a later edition is specifically connected to Douin: 'Nouveaux voyages dans l'Amérique Septentrionale, contenant une collection de lettres écrites sur les lieux, par l'auteur à son ami, M. Douin ... ci-devant son camarade dans le Nouveau monde' (Amsterdam: Changuion, 1777). The only work from our period indentified with an author called Douin concerning a subject connected to the 'Indes' is  the 'Mémoire apolégetique [i.e., apologétique] de M. Douin de la Motte: chevalier, capitaine d'une compagnie detachée de la marine au cap, Ile St. Domingue: contenant ses griefs contre Monsieur le comte d'Estaing (Charleston [S.C.]: De l'impr. de Pierre Timothée, 1765). Certain Commissioned STN edition Pièces importantes à la dernière revolution de Genève Mémoire apologetique des Genevois; Pièces de Geneve; Pieces importantes relatives a la derniere rev de Geneve NA NA French J.-L. Pellet Société Typographique de Neuchâtel Geneva Neuchâtel 1782 1782 27 27 1 NA NA NA NA Attribution - this work is usually called 'Mémoire apologetique des Genevois' in STN sources, probably a case of deliberate encryption. However, the correct title appears in some STN sources. John Jeanprêtre 'Histoire de la Société typographique de Neuchâtel', p. 13 [p.117 in the original printing of the article in the Musée Neuchâtelois, 1949] indicates that a receipt in the STN accounts for the 5,000 copies sent to Chauvet makes clear that the two works are one and the same. The putative publisher Pellet traditionally allowed his name to be used as a cover for semi-clandestine works including the 'Encyclopédie' - see 'Cinq siècles de l'imprimerie Genevoise' p. 73. It appears likely that sales of this work in July-September 1782 may relate to an earlier STN printing or separate edition. This work is missing from Schmidt's 'Liste des impressions'. We thank Robert Darnton for indicating the true identity of the 'Mémoire apologétique des Genevois' and supplying the Jeanprêtre reference. Pièces importantes à la dernière revolution de Genève

Pseudo Place of publication unknown Mémoires justificatifs de la comtesse de Valois de La Motte Mémoires de la motte NA NA French NA NA London ? 1789 NA NA NA 3 NA 18 NA NA Attribution - edition not identified, several produced. No three volume edition is known. The third volume was sourced separately from the first two volumes and was presumably either the spurious 'Second Mémoire justificatif de la Comtesse de la Motte' (London, 1789) or equally spurious 'La Reine dévoilée, ou supplément au Mémoire de Mde la comtesse de La Motte' (London, 1789). Textual and other evidence suggests that neither work was written by the countess. A second, posthumously published version of the Countess's memoirs appeared in 1791, a year after the STN transactions recorded. See Burrows, 'Blackmail, Scandal, and Revolution.' Mémoires justificatifs de la comtesse de Valois de La Motte

NA NA NA NA 1 NA NA NA NA Attribution - edition not identified, several produced.  Superbook attribution uncertain - manuscript information gives 'histoire de Du barry' and later 'histoire secrete dubarry'. Although a biography of Du Barry formed only part of the 'Gazette de Cythère', the current title was often given as the sub-title of the 'Gazette de Cythère'. Although no extant example of the 'Histoire secrète' has been found as a stand alone publication (ie. published or bound separately from the rest of the Gazette de Cythère) under the title given here, it is sometimes encountered in isolation under an alternative title, the 'Précis historique de la vie de Mad. la comtesse du Barry'. Given this information, it has been assumed that the 'Histoire secrète' probably relates to the integral text of the 'Gazette de Cythère'. Author attribution after Quérard and Octave Uzanne. Gazette (la) de Cythère

Schmidt, 'Liste des Impressions' (Annexe) lists a 1782 printing of the fifth edition but extant copies and Fauche-Borel catalogue (1787) give date as 1783. This may indicate that there were two printings, but sales data suggests more likely a change of title page, presumably due to slower than expected sales. Nevertheless, this work went through several more editions through until 1831. (The first known edition dates from 1761). Cours abrégé de géographie historique

Troisième édition Géographie élémentaire NA NA French Société Typographique de Neuchâtel NA Neuchâtel Neuchâtel 1770 NA 96 96 1 NA NA NA NA Attribution - known STN edition published simultaneously as a stand alone edition with a print-run of 1,500 and an edition contained within the 'Cours abrégé de géographie historique, ancienne & moderne, et de sphère: par demandes et réponses. Troisième édition', of which it occupied the first 96 pages of volume 1, and (for its table) the last 2 pages of volume 2. NB. The combined edition is recorded under the superbook '[Géographie par Ostervald]'. Géographie élémentaire

Certain Livres en Société: STN joint editions Géographie élémentaire. Cinquième édition Géographie élémentaire NA NA French Société Typographique de Neuchâtel NA Neuchâtel Neuchâtel 1782-1783 1782 108 108 1 NA 12 NA NA Attribution - known STN edition. Sales and stocktake data suggests a limited printing in early 1782 and much larger one at the end of the year, presumably the 1783 edition. Schmidt, 'Liste des impressions' annexe records a 1782 edition that has not been located, whereas a 1783 edition is extant. Both editions are described as the 5th edition, so they are treated as one edition with (apparently) two printings here. BPUN copy of 1783 edition is bundled with the 'Cours abrégé de géographie historique', 5th edition, 1783. Géographie élémentaire

Certain Other Swiss editions La raison par alphabet: ou suplément aux Questions sur l'Encyclopédie atribué à divers hommes célèbres Suplément aux question; Supplément aux questions NA NA French NA François Grasset & comp. London Lausanne 1776 NA vi, 359 365 1 NA 8 23 NA Attribution - supplied by Grasset and recorded under the sub-title 'Supplément aux Questions'. This work was the eighth and final volume of Grasset's edition of the 'Questions sur l'Encyclopédie' reissued under a new title and title-page bearing the date of publication 1776. The final page of the edition even carries the wording 'Fin du tome VIII'. The 'Questions sur l'Encyclopédie' itself formed vols 40-47 of Grasset's 'Collection complette des oeuvres de Mr. de Voltaire,' and were originally published in 1775. The articles in this volume ranged from 'Abbe' to 'Vertu', but are not the same material as found in the 'Supplément' at the end of the 1772 STN edition of the 'Questions sur l'Encyclopédie', which formed the last part of volume IX. Although the STN first received copies of 'La Raison par alphabet' in October 1775, it was standard practice in the final months of one year to issue works bearing the next year's date. 'La Raison par alphabet' is not recorded in Biblos 18. La raison par alphabet

Certain Swiss-International editions Encyclopédie, ou Dictionnaire raisonné des sciences, des arts et des métiers 397; Encyclopédie NA NA French NA Joseph Duplain; Panckoucke; Société Typographique de Neuchâtel Geneva; Neuchâtel Lyons; Neuchâtel 1778-1779 NA NA NA 39 NA 4 NA NA Attribution - known edition.   N.B. Although this third edition of the 'Encyclopédie', comprising 36 vols of text and 3 of plates, claimed to be published 'A Genève: chez Jean-Léonard Pellet; à Neuchâtel chez la Société typographique', it was in reality, as Robert Darnton has shown, produced on behalf of Joseph Duplain and his associates in several different printshops. According to the STN's 'Banque des ouvriers' for 1776-9 the STN produced volumes 6, 15, 19, 24, and 35. Purchases of paper for these volumes have also been traced by Darnton ('Business of Enlightenment', pp. 190-1). Based on the STN's copy of Duplain's subscription register (BPUN MS 1220), supplemented by other documents, Darnton has reconstructed and mapped the distribution in Europe of Duplain’s 8,011 subscriptions, mostly sold to booksellers (Business of Enlightenment, Appendix B). Our figures do not draw on this source and only account for copies which went through the regular accounts of the STN. Encyclopédie

Pseudo Place of publication unknown Dieu (de) 320; Dieu (de) NA NA French NA NA n.pl. ? NA 1785? [2], 28 30 1 NA 8 NA L'édition neuchâteloise... says no archival evidence for this being a STN edition.  Could this possibly be an unknown Louis Sebastien Mercier edition? Or is 'Mercier' David Mercier, the STN's commis? Attribution - edition attributed to the STN by Schmidt 'sujette à caution', as text is dated "A Neuchatel en Suisse, le premier janvier 1785". However attribution to STN is surely incorrect, as MS1007 records the only 16 copies STN traded as coming from 'Mercier' 31 May 1785. No sales are recorded in MS1007. This pamphlet does not appear to have been previously attributed to Louis-Sébastien Mercier, although he is certainly the author: the text was included in the fourth volume of his 'Mon Bonnet de Nuit', which also appeared in 1785. Certain STN editions Descriptions des arts et métiers [planches] Description des arts planches NA NA French Société Typographique de Neuchâtel NA Neuchâtel Neuchâtel NA NA NA NA 19 NA NA NA NA Attribution - known STN edition.  N.B. Along with the ‘Encyclopédie’, the STNs edition of the ‘Description des Arts’ was a lengthy and complicated undertaking that, largely due to subscription sales, did not always pass through the society’s accounts in the same fashion of ‘normal’ books.  The FBTEE project methodology has allowed us to reconstruct many of the sales, but data given should be considered incomplete. Because of this, no attempt has been made to give assumed printing runs and dates. The STNs recording of their shipments of the 'planches' was especially inconsistent and thus the data incomplete. Descriptions des arts et métiers

Pseudo Place of publication unknown [Encyclopédie - Table analytique et raisonnée des matieres contenues...] Table analytique NA NA French NA NA n.pl. ? NA NA NA NA 1 NA NA NA NA N.B. Along with the ‘Description des Arts’, the STNs edition of the ‘Encyclopédie’ was a lengthy and complicated undertaking that, largely due to subscription sales, did not always pass through the society’s accounts in the same fashion of ‘normal’ books.  The FBTEE project methodology has allowed us to reconstruct many of the sales of the various editions, but data given should be considered incomplete. Because of this, no attempt has been made to give assumed printing runs and dates. For a more complete publishing history see Darnton ‘The Business of Enlightenment’. Encyclopédie

Pseudo Place of publication unknown Songes (les) physiques, ou diverses questions problématiques, avec les différentes réponses, répliques ou réfutations qui ont été faites sur chacune de ces questions   Songes physiques NA NA French NA NA n.pl. ? NA NA NA NA 1 NA NA NA NA Notes: Attribution not certain. Library cataloguers do not seem to have picked up that the 1753 materialist work of this title published in Amsterdam by Louis Malo Moreau de Saint-Elier, the brother of Maupertuis, is a very different text from a Christian-inspired work published in Amsterdam in 1781 under the title 'Les Songes physiques, ou diverses questions problématiques, avec les différentes réponses, répliques ou réfutations qui ont été faites sur chacune de ces questions'. As the STN acquired this work in 1787 it seems more likely to have been the latter, which although frequently attributed to Moreau de Saint-Elier, was presumably by another hand. Songes (les) physiques

Pseudo Place of publication unknown Instructions d'un père à ses enfans 1585; 704; 705; Etrennes d'un pere à ses enfans; Instruction de Trembley sur la vertu; Instruction sur la vérité de Trembley; Instructions de Chirol; Instructions de Trembley; Instructions de Trembley sur la religion naturelle; Instructions d'un père à ses enfans; Instructions d'un père à ses enfans sur la religion; Instructions par Trembley; Instructions sur la vertu; Trembley; Trembley sur le bonheur NA NA French NA NA n.pl. ? NA NA NA NA 1 NA 8 NA 1776 or earlier Attribution - several editions of the 'Instructions d'un père à ses enfans, sur le principe de la vertu et du bonheur', 'Instructions d'un père à ses enfans sur la religion naturelle et révélée' and 'Instructions d'un père à ses enfans sur la nature et sur la religion' all by Trembley were produced in Geneva and Neuchâtel from 1775. They existed in 2, 3, 5 or 6 volumes according to how they were bundled together. The STN often accounted for various versions of the title under simply 'Instructions d'un père à ses enfans', often without volume information, and thus in the majority of cases it is not possible to verify exactly which edition was being sold. The (Neuchâtel, 1779) Samuel Fauche edition, in 2 volumes makes up many of the sales, but versions produced by Chirol in Geneva in 1779 and 1783 were also traded. The STN also accounted for this work as 'oeuvres de Trembley' (and variations upon this title) and 'Trembley complet'. Instructions d'un père à ses enfans

Probable Other Swiss editions Preuve indépendante de toute autre, de la vérité de la religion chrétienne; ou Considérations sur la conversion & l'apostolat de St. Paul ... Traduit de l'anglois, par Jean Des Champs ... Seconde édition revue & corrigée. Littleton; littleton verite de la religion; Traité de la vérité de la religion; Traité des vérites de la réligion Observations on the conversion and apostleship of St. Paul. English French Bousquet NA Lausanne Lausanne 1758 NA 134 134 1 NA 12 NA NA Attribution - sourced from Lausanne, only edition published under this title. Bousquet's preface (pp. ix-x) tells us that there was an edition produced in Amsterdam in 1751. He decided to make a new edition and therefore contacted Lord Lyttleton, who gave Bousquet his approbation, and the original translator, Jean Deschamps, gave Bousquet extensive notes, amendments and additions. The previous edition had a slightly different title, for Bosquet says he was the first to use the word 'Considerations' in the title. Bousquet also mentions a 1754 Parisian translation that he considered more elegant but less faithful to the original text.  Preuve indépendante de toute autre, de la vérité de la religion chrétienne

Pseudo Place of publication unknown [Frédéric le grand] Fréderic le grand NA NA French NA NA n.pl. ? NA NA NA NA 1 NA NA NA NA Attribution - work not identified. Almost certainly a version of the 'Oeuvres posthumes de Frédérick II'. These commissions represent only a small fragment of those that Durand received for this work on his travels. However the majority of these orders were for a proposed edition by a confederation of Swiss booksellers from which the STN pulled out at the last minute. They almost certainly did not realise these other orders and they have thus not been included in the database. See Freedman 'Before Nationalism', for a detailed history of the affair. [Frédéric le grand]

NA NA NA NA 1 NA NA NA NA Attribution - The Durand Sales Tour dossier records sales and purchases handled by the STN agent Durand while away from Neuchâtel on a business tour lasting from 29th July 1787, when he left Berne, to his arrival in Lausanne on the 19th November 1788. To save time, and possibly hide sales of forbidden works, his correspondence used numerical codes for each work, which can be cross-referenced with the item numbers in Louis Fauche-Borel's 1787 catalogue and supplement. We have been unable to locate a second supplement which he used later in the tour, so works with numbers corresponding to those in this second catalogue have been recorded together here as 'unidentified Durand Tour Works'. [Unidentified Durand Tour Works]
